content:
Starting With High Hopes I signed up for the Jakarta 150 km Audax imagining a steady day in the saddle, easy pace, friendly banter at checkpoints, maybe even an iced kopi somewhere along the way. What I got was the exact opposite.
Heat, Flats, and Muddy Roads The sun showed up early and refused to leave. By kilometer 20 it felt like every pedal stroke was being grilled into the asphalt. And then, before I even made it to the first checkpoint, the rear tire went soft. No sag wagon, no neutral support, just me, my tools, and Jakarta heat turning every minute into a test of patience.
The GPX did not cut me any slack either, muddy backroads, gravel patches, and detours that chewed up both bike and rider.
Almost DNF Near Fatmawati About 5 km from Fatmawati Hospital I hit a low that surprised me. I just wanted to DNF. Everything in me wanted to stop. But there was also a strange, sudden happiness at being that close to the finish, like relief and disbelief mixed together. I told myself, I believe I can, and kept turning the pedals.
Snapped Chain, Stubborn Finish As if that was not enough, the chain snapped just 7 km from the finish. Greasy fingers, shaky hands, one spare link, somehow I managed to piece it back together. Unsupported means exactly that, no one is coming. So I kept rolling.
When I finally crossed the finish, jersey caked in salt and mind running on fumes, it felt like debugging life line by line, messy, frustrating, but worth every keystroke. Jakarta peeled me apart that day. Mud, busted chain, flat tire before checkpoint one, and the kind of heat that makes you hallucinate. But I still finished. That is the only line of code that matters.
summary:
Starting With High Hopes

I signed up for the Jakarta 150 km Audax imagining a steady day in the saddle, easy pace, friendly banter at checkpoints, maybe even an iced kopi somewhere along the way. What I got was the exact opposite.

Heat, Flats, and Muddy Roads

The sun showed up early and refused to leave. By kilometer 20 it felt like every pedal stroke was being grilled into the asphalt. And then, before I even made it to the first checkpoint, the rear tire went soft. No sag wagon, no neutral support, just me, my tools, and Jakarta heat turning every minute into a test of patience.
title: Audax 150KM Jakarta: Unsupported and Unbroken

content:
Ramadhan Stories A few months back, around Ramadan, I stumbled into an anime I totally misjudged.
Thought it was some weird horror or action thing (title had Orb in it, so yeah, I expected punching or blood or something like that).
Turns out… it was about geocentric vs. heliocentric theory.
Earth-centered vs. Sun-centered.
And the madness people faced when they tried to prove something the world wasn‚Äôt ready to accept.
Didn‚Äôt expect to feel anything.
Instead, I got wrecked.
It felt too real Watching someone dedicate their entire life to a truth and still get rejected … damn.
That broke something inside me.
It felt too real. Like the kind of pain you can‚Äôt argue with: the pain of being right, too early.
My Mind went elsewhere And suddenly, my mind went elsewhere.
I started thinking about Prophet Muhammad Ô∑∫.
He wasn‚Äôt trying to prove planets move.
He was trying to guide hearts.
Things we’re still figuring out He didn‚Äôt come with formulas or telescopes.
But the Qur‚Äôan talks about the cosmos, the heavens, the universe expanding, and yeah … things we‚Äôre still figuring out.
And then there‚Äôs Isra Mi‚Äôraj.
A journey through the heavens.
Outside of time, outside of reason, and yet… it happened.
He came back with prayer. Not theories.
And I thought:
He could‚Äôve had peace. A quiet life.
But he chose the heavy path .. for us.
Science & Faith That anime made me feel a lot.
Like… science and faith don‚Äôt have to fight.
Sometimes they meet.
In a verse. In a telescope. In a broken moment.
Or yeah, even in some random anime at 2AM during Ramadan üòÖ
Truth, whether uncovered through research, or held by faith,
it’s still truth
and it still shines.
Thanks for being here.
That moment during Ramadan still lingers in my head.
Sometimes, the most meaningful things come from places you weren‚Äôt even looking.
still me,
Agung ‚ú®s
summary:
Ramadhan Stories

A few months back, around Ramadan, I stumbled into an anime I totally misjudged.
Thought it was some weird horror or action thing (title had Orb in it, so yeah, I expected punching or blood or something like that).

Turns out… it was about geocentric vs. heliocentric theory.
Earth-centered vs. Sun-centered.
And the madness people faced when they tried to prove something the world wasn‚Äôt ready to accept.
title: A Ramadan Reflection ~ üòÖ Late Post

content:
It all started with Patrick.
Not a person. A bike.
A junk Chinese gravel bike I bought for 600K from the cursed depths of Shitpee (yeah, Shopee)
Before it was Patrick, it was just… tragic.
White frame.
Shitty red decals that looked like knock-off fire graphics.
I thought stickers would save it.
So I went full Jaksel-core: anime, fake brands, nonsense logos.
It looked worse.
But I don‚Äôt know why‚Ä¶
I loved that damn bike.
Maybe because it didn‚Äôt care what it looked like.
It just kept rolling, no questions asked.
Then came the pain rides:
Audax 200KM: finished, but missed the cut-off. Still proud. JBR (Jakarta Bronx Border Ride): my legs never forgave me, where bike lanes go to die. GXID a.k.a Jakarta Ride: routes designed by psychopaths with GPS. Depok U-Series: 130KM + 1300m elev. For fun? Nope. For trauma. After all that, I said:
“You know what, this frame deserves better.”
So I called Psychloop in Darmawangsa:
‚ÄúBro, repaint this thing. Name it Patrick.‚Äù
Boom. Patrick was born.
A fresh coat of class over years of chaos.
While I was there, I made the dumbest smart move:
Bought MKS Solution pedals, pure Japan smoothness.
2x the price of the MXL frame.
Worth it?
Financially, no.
Spiritually? Yes.
Patrick‚Äôs Final Form: GRX 10-speed üõ†Ô∏è Entity Expert 400mm dropbar (clearance steal from Rodalink üôè) Dia-Compe bar-end shifters (retro + regret = realness) TRP Spyre mechanical disc brakes WTB 700x37 tires (thicc, slow, dramatic) Repainted & reborn as Patrick by Psychloop MKS Solution pedals (because why not go bankrupt?) 600K MXL frame that survived hell and paint What I Learned: Don‚Äôt upgrade trash‚Ä¶ unless you want a story Love makes you do dumb things, like $80 pedals on a $40 frame Stickers don‚Äôt fix ugly Gravel ‚â† comfort Dumb bikes + dumber owners = beautiful chaos Dumb bike. Dumber owner. Still riding.
üíö Still broke. Still proud. Still here.
summary:
It all started with Patrick.
Not a person. A bike.
A junk Chinese gravel bike I bought for 600K from the cursed depths of Shitpee (yeah, Shopee)

Before it was Patrick, it was just… tragic.
White frame.

Shitty red decals that looked like knock-off fire graphics.
I thought stickers would save it.
So I went full Jaksel-core: anime, fake brands, nonsense logos.
It looked worse.

But I don‚Äôt know why‚Ä¶
I loved that damn bike.
Maybe because it didn‚Äôt care what it looked like.
It just kept rolling, no questions asked.
title: Dumb Bike, Dumber Owner  ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüö≤

content:
Why It Wasn‚Äôt What I Expected For as long as I can remember, I thought life was supposed to follow a straight line. You pick a dream when you‚Äôre young: astronaut, architect, rockstar, whatever, and then you chase it down, step by step. That‚Äôs what we‚Äôre told, anyway.
But here‚Äôs what nobody tells you: most of us end up somewhere completely different. We blink, years pass, and suddenly we‚Äôre not the people we once imagined.
Staring at the Mirror (And Not Recognizing Who‚Äôs There) I‚Äôve had more than a few moments where I looked in the mirror and thought, ‚ÄúWho is this?‚Äù
Not in a dramatic, movie-meltdown kind of way, just a quiet, subtle sense of not recognizing the version of myself looking back.
Every era of my life feels like it belonged to a different person:
The one who thought he‚Äôd be an esports player or a band player. The one who ended up in digital marketing, which was never on my vision board. The one who got back into coding after years away. The cyclist, chasing sunrise rides and sore legs instead of‚Ä¶ whatever I thought adulthood was supposed to be. The Unexpected Turns I never set out to be a digital marketer.
I didn‚Äôt imagine I‚Äôd be the kind of person who finds joy in analytics dashboards or debugging someone‚Äôs messy code at midnight.
And I definitely never saw myself obsessing over cycling gear, logging kilometers like I was training for the Tour de France.
Sometimes I wonder if I‚Äôm living in someone else‚Äôs body, a stranger who just happens to share my name and a few old memories.
Losing and Finding ‚ÄúYou‚Äù Songs like Bowie‚Äôs The Man Who Sold the World or Gotye‚Äôs Somebody That I Used to Know hit me because they‚Äôre about exactly this:
Looking back and seeing a stranger in your own story. Wondering if you ‚Äúsold out,‚Äù or just grew up. If you lost control, or simply changed.
We all become ‚Äúsomebody I used to know‚Äù at some point, and that‚Äôs okay.
The Truth: You‚Äôre Always Becoming If I‚Äôve learned anything, it‚Äôs this: finding yourself isn‚Äôt a destination.
It‚Äôs a constant, messy, beautiful process of becoming, letting go of the old versions and meeting the new ones, over and over.
Some days I miss the person I thought I‚Äôd be.
Most days, though, I‚Äôm grateful for the one I‚Äôve become, even if I had no idea he was coming.
Because in the end, you don‚Äôt find yourself all at once.
You find yourself a little bit every day, in every surprise, every detour, every mirror.
summary:
Why It Wasn‚Äôt What I Expected

For as long as I can remember, I thought life was supposed to follow a straight line. You pick a dream when you‚Äôre young: astronaut, architect, rockstar, whatever, and then you chase it down, step by step. That‚Äôs what we‚Äôre told, anyway.

But here‚Äôs what nobody tells you: most of us end up somewhere completely different. We blink, years pass, and suddenly we‚Äôre not the people we once imagined.
title: How I Found Myself

content:
I don‚Äôt even know where to start. Maybe this blog exists out of ego. Maybe it‚Äôs just me trying to fix the mess I made with rasastroberi, a blog I once loved, hated, and at one point thought about killing (along with the part of me that made it). Or maybe it‚Äôs an attempt to bury alkind_COOL, a name so cringe I still flinch thinking about it.
Anyway‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm glad you’re here. This space, agungsukariman.com, is gonna be my place to dump thoughts. I‚Äôll talk about digital marketing, tech stuff, dead or dying SEO tricks, tools I like, music I listen to, things I‚Äôm building, breaking, or obsessed with. Nothing too formal. Just notes from my head to yours.
Let‚Äôs see where this goes.

content:
Smart Salary Employer branding campaigns needed to feed a nationwide hiring pipeline. I rebuilt the analytics foundation, stitched conversion APIs back into the CRM, and automated Looker Studio reports so HR and paid teams shared the same targets every week.
Highlights
Lifted qualified applicant volume by 36% over three months without increasing spend Connected Meta, Google, and LinkedIn campaign data to Salesforce for daily lead scoring Delivered alerting that caught broken tracking within the first hour WeAreFum A boutique cycling retailer needed clarity on every rupiah spent online. Together we cleaned GA4 and server-side tagging, deployed pixel health monitoring, and launched a quarterly optimisation structure that made creative testing routine.
Highlights
Built product-level dashboards that merged Shopify, GA4, and Meta conversions Automated campaign and SKU pacing reports with BigQuery + Apps Script Improved return on ad spend by 28% by week six of consistent optimisation Other Collaborations Beyond these flagship projects, I partner with founders and marketing teams on data migrations, attribution clean-ups, and ‚Äúbrownout‚Äù rescues when reporting silently fails. If your stack needs similar triage, reach out.
summary: Selected case studies from brands and SMEs I support.
title: Projects

content: Tracking Setup GA4 and server-side tagging architectures that capture the right events from day one Conversion APIs, consent mode, and cross-domain tracking that stay compliant Analytics QA so platforms, CRMs, and warehouses tell the same story Reporting Automation Dashboards built on Looker Studio, BigQuery, or the tools your operators already use Data pipelines, scripts, and alerts that keep metrics fresh without the manual grind Campaign, finance, and product views tailored to how your leadership reads performance Ad Optimisation Media mix reviews that connect creative, targeting, and spend to business outcomes Experiment frameworks that blend platform data with first-party signals Monthly and quarterly optimisation loops that surface what to scale and what to stop Need support on something more custom? Let‚Äôs talk.
summary: Tracking setup, reporting automation, and ad optimisation.

title: Contact

content:
The truth is, Agung was never meant to be my name. My mom wanted Agus, you know, the classic Indo name, mass-produced like mie instan üçú. But maybe that‚Äôs the problem. Too many Aguses walking around. So my dad came through with Agung. Sounds like some Bali prince or gamelan prodigy‚Ä¶ but nope. Just me. Not Balinese. Just‚Ä¶ here.
Sukariman? That‚Äôs a whole other drama.
SU from Sulastri, my mom, the real MVP.
KARIM, from the Karim family, who literally picked baby me up from the hospital when my parents were broke. No grab, no gojek, just pure kindness ‚ù§Ô∏è
And MAN? That‚Äôs for Basman, my dad. Or as I like to call it‚Ä¶ Bestman. Lols.
So yeah, even my name is a mashup of love, struggle, and last-minute decisions üé≤
I was supposed to be in a band üé∏. Or an esports team üéÆ. Or I dunno, doing something that didn‚Äôt involve debugging tracking scripts at 2am. Not to mention that one dream: becoming a Game Master at Netmarble. Yup. I really thought I’d be managing MMORPG servers, banning cheaters, and giving away item codes like Oprah. Life said nope.
But here I am, writing, clicking, optimizing pixels, and biking long rides üö¥‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è like I‚Äôm running away from my own roadmap.
Sometimes I look in the mirror and think: am I really living the life I thought I would? Probably not. But at least I‚Äôm still moving. Still me. Just weirder now.
This blog? Don‚Äôt expect perfection. Expect detours, noise, unfinished thoughts, and maybe a few dead jokes along the way üíÄ
Somewhere between the missed gigs and broken bikes, I picked up a different craft: making pixels tell the truth. Tracking stacks, campaign diagnostics, SEO on sites that swear they are ‚Äúfine‚Äù until we open Search Console. If you need someone who can translate business goals into dashboards, fix the tags that feed them, and still speak human, that is the version of me you will meet here. The story is messy, but the work is sharp.

Too many Aguses walking around. So my dad came through with Agung. Sounds like some Bali prince or gamelan prodigy‚Ä¶ but nope. Just me. Not Balinese. Just‚Ä¶ here.

Sukariman? That‚Äôs a whole other drama.

SU from Sulastri, my mom, the real MVP.
KARIM, from the Karim family, who literally picked baby me up from the hospital when my parents were broke. No grab, no gojek, just pure kindness ‚ù§Ô∏è
And MAN? That‚Äôs for Basman, my dad. Or as I like to call it‚Ä¶ Bestman. Lols.
